intro: Paracorokia, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its long, narrow leaves that are often used in traditional Māori weaving. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers that bloom in clusters at the base of the leaves. Paracorokia thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and lowland areas. Its fibrous leaves have been historically valued for their versatility in crafting and cultural practices.
